captions.text:
Whether you're cold, scared or listening to
some great music, you've likely

experienced goosebumps at some point in
your life.  But have you ever wondered why

this strange change takes over your
body?  Named after the way poultry looks
when plucked, goosebumps are a fairly useless trait in humans which have been passed

on by our ancestors.  Each hair actually
has a tiny muscle attached to it called

the erector-pili muscles and when these
muscles contract the hair stands up on

end.  This contraction creates a shallow
depression around the hair causing the

surrounding area to protrude.  And it's
the stress hormone adrenaline which

triggers this physiological change to
occur.  So what triggers adrenaline?  For

one being cold, in animals with much more
hair on their body this response helps

them to stay warm.  The standing hair is
able to trap more air and thermal

regulate it ultimately providing an
insulated barrier.  Apart from this

adrenaline is also triggered under
stressful situations leading to the

"fight or flight" response, like when
you're scared.  Cats are a perfect example,

if you give them a spook their hair
shoots up on end.

This involuntary evolutionary response
allows animals to appear bigger and

more intimidating.  But why music has the
ability to cause chills or "frisson" as

it's called is not fully understood.  One
interesting theory suggests that

elements of music such as sudden volume
changes or unexpected unique sections

induce a sub-conscious fear response.  The
body loves predictability and so

anything surprising to the autonomic
system stimulates an alarm.  But this fear

quickly subsides as our brain realizes,
"hey, it's just music".  And this contrast in

experience causes the frisson
and your goosebumps.  There are other

theories as well, ultimately the brain
is extremely complex and so a relationship

between music, emotion and physiological
responses is difficult to decipher but

in science it's okay to say that we
don't know...yet.
Got a burning question you want answered?  Ask it in the comments or on facebook and twitter.

And subscribe to more weekly science
videos.

title: The Science of Goosebumps and Music Chills

comments.text:
I think it has to do with the fact that we enjoy music more when it 
resonates in our bones (for example, a really loud concert w/ earplugs is 
still more enjoyable than music on a somewhat lower volume), and when we 
speak, or sing in this case, our bones resonate as well.
Might also be because music is about a sense of belonging and being part of 
a group, because when listening to music your internal rhythm synchronises 
with it, and when you sing along you're more 'synced' with the song.
No sources on this, just my idea on it.

comments.text:
+Andrea Langley Sharp
Songs definitely resonate with the time period we associate them with. 
Probably why for example the song 'Teenage Dirtbag', though I find nothing 
particularly endearing about it, on the rare occasion they play it on the 
radio it takes me back to exactly where my life was in late 2000...
comments.author: razeezar

comments.text:
Pop's appeal is complex; it involves lyrics that are generic enough to 
appeal to most listeners' own experiences (or desires) and psychological 
tactics such as musical hooks, exploitation of desires (attractive 
voices/bodies, physical or emotional idealism), and (quite powerfully) 
marketing. It never gives me goosebumps either (lol). Perhaps the lack of 
strong emotional response makes pop music the "soundtrack of my immediate 
present" it is.

music as well, and also from certain voices.

comments.author: Jenny Plasky

comments.text:
I think goosbumps and music is still a result of the same process you 
described with the cat being afraid. I think its human nature to get 
ourselves all riled up before battle the same way packs of chimpanzees or 
wolves, or really early ancestors of humans probably did resulting in 
heightened adrenaline to counteract the (what I believe) extremely large 
amounts of fear and nervousness that would be present. Music represents a 
theme, or idea, or belief to the person enjoying it enough to get goosbumps 
-- in the same way a leader or alpha animal would before a battle or hunt. 
Music riles us up for 21st century battle -- which for us 1st-worlders is 
largely an emotional one... we must fight off the negativity internalized 
from living in our ranked and unfair society and the arts in my opinion, 
have always been a mechanism to fight off different examples of negative 
aspects of having an intelligence﻿
comments.author: umbrellaBuddha
